item.title: Live Updates: Macron Holds Off Far-Right Push in France
item.description: Marine Le Pen concedes defeat to President Emmanuel Macron, the first French leader to be re-elected since 2002.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polling station in Paris on Sunday.

item.title: How the Ex-Chancellor Gerhard Schröder Became Putin’s Man in Germany
item.description: Gerhard Schröder, who is paid almost $1 million a year by Russian-controlled energy companies, has become a pariah. But he is also a symbol of Germany’s Russia policy.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gerhard Schröder served as the chancellor for Germany from 1998 to 2005.

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Commander Says Mariupol Steel Plant Hasn’t Fallen
item.description: A Ukrainian commander inside the plant spoke to The Times, as Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III were expected in Kyiv on Sunday. Details of their trip had not yet been released.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers Sunday at a base in the Zaporizhzhia region, in southeast Ukraine.

item.title: At Least 10 Dead After Tour Boat Sinks in Japan
item.description: Sixteen people were still missing, more than 24 hours after the sightseeing vessel was lost off the coast of Hokkaido island.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Makiko Inoue
item.media:credit: Jiji Press/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescuers on the Japanese island of Hokkaido on Sunday. Officials said 16 people were still missing after a boat accident.

item.title: An American Consulting Firm Became a Power Broker, and Then a Pariah, in South Africa
item.description: A new judicial inquiry found that corruption at South Africa’s tax agency was because of “collusion” between Bain & Company and South Africa’s former president.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Jerome Delay
item.media:description: Jacob Zuma, the former president of South Africa, speaking to his lawyers in January at the high court in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa.

item.title: Discreetly, the Young in Japan Chip Away at a Taboo on Tattoos
item.description: Exposed to body art on social media, more young Japanese are getting tattoos, even if that means hiding them at work.
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Haruka Sakaguchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asami said he worried about some in the younger generation who ignore signs banning tattoos or take newly secured privileges for granted.

item.title: Warsaw’s Welcome Mat Risks Fraying Under Strain of a New Refugee Surge
item.description: Warsaw gladly and proudly accepted 300,000 Ukrainians fleeing the war. But as the Polish capital braces for a new wave of refugees, its mayor warns that the city is “at capacity.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian refugees crossing the border into Poland at Medyka last month.

item.title: Rattled by Ukraine War, Moldova Strives to Dodge Russia’s Long Shadow
item.description: Moldova’s destiny has been intertwined uncomfortably with Russia’s for years, and the Ukraine invasion has accelerated its efforts to break free from Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Soviet-era monument in Chisinau, the capital of Moldova, in March. The war in Ukraine has stoked fears in Moldova of renewed pressures from Russia.

item.title: Who Will France’s Muslims Choose for President?
item.description: French Muslims face a decision between Emmanuel Macron, whose presidency some of them view as harmful, and Marine Le Pen, whose far-right party has a history of anti-Muslim positions.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Aida Alami
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Mosque of Bondy, in the Seine-Saint-Denis region outside Paris, where anger among Muslims toward President Emmanuel Macron and his challenger, Marine Le Pen, runs strong.

item.title: One Ukrainian War Casualty: The World’s Largest Airplane
item.description: Mriya, the world’s largest aircraft, was destroyed in a pivotal battle at the start of the war. It was a beloved symbol for all of Ukraine but perhaps no one misses it more than its first pilot.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleksandr Halunenko, the first pilot of Mriya, surveying damage to the world's largest cargo aircraft at the Antonov airfield in Hostomel, near Kyiv.

item.title: A Site Holy to Jews and Muslims Returns as the Nexus of Conflict
item.description: The skirmishes between Palestinians and Israeli police at the Aqsa Mosque, known to Jews as Temple Mount, are laden with national and religious symbolism.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Ammar Awad/Reuters
item.media:description: Palestinian protesters at the Aqsa Mosque compound on Friday.

item.title: Afghanistan Mosque Explosion Kills 33
item.description: The blast in Kunduz Province, in the north, was the latest in a series of attacks reminiscent of the past two decades of war.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A child being treated for injuries at a hospital in Kunduz after a bomb blast earlier this week, on Thursday.

item.title: President Moon Exchanges Farewell Letters With Kim Jong-un
item.description: President Moon Jae-in, who is barred from seeking re-election after his five-year term, and the North’s leader had warm parting words amid a diplomatic stalemate.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korea Summit Press Pool, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and President Moon Jae-in of South Korea holding hands at the border line between their two countries, in 2018.

item.title: E.U. Takes Aim at Social Media’s Harms With Landmark New Law
item.description: The Digital Services Act would force Meta, Google and others to combat misinformation and restrict certain online ads. How European officials will wield it remains to be seen.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Gabriel Bouys/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Since Europe’s General Data Protection Regulation took effect in 2018, little action has been taken against the data-collection practices of large internet platforms.

item.title: Modi Stresses Growth, Sidestepping Politics, in Visit to Restive Territory
item.description: The Indian prime minister aims to ease decades of turmoil in Jammu and Kashmir through projects like a solar plant.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Channi Anand/Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, sitting center and shown on a big screen, was flanked by regional officials on Sunday in a visit to Palli, a village in Jammu, India.

item.title: Ukrainians in Mariupol’s Steel Plant Are Holding On, a Commander Tells the Times
item.description: Capt. Svyatoslav Palamar says he and others would give up the factory if they could leave safely.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Alexander Ermochenko/Reuters
item.media:description: The Azovstal iron and steel plant, in the background, in the southern port city of Mariupol, Ukraine, last week.

item.title: Emmanuel Macron Defeats Marine Le Pen in French Presidential Election
item.description: Mr. Macron, who held off a challenge from the far right, is the first incumbent president to win re-election in France since 2002.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Emmanuel Macron reacting as results were announced Sunday evening in Paris.

item.title: Turbulence or tradition? What to expect once the election ends.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ludovic Marin
item.media:description: The Élysée Palace in 2020. Newly elected leaders are welcomed at the palace by their predecessors for a handover meeting.

item.title: Demolishing City of the Dead Will Displace a Lively Quarter of Cairo
item.description: Cairo’s oldest cemetery is being razed, and thousands of families living amid the grand mausoleums face eviction. “You’re not at ease when you’re living. You’re not at ease even when you’re dead.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Heba Khamis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of Cairo’s oldest cemetery, both the living and the dead, are facing eviction. The carved antique wooden doors and marble have aleady been removed from many mausoleums.

item.title: With Us or With Them? In a New Cold War, How About Neither.
item.description: Old geopolitical foes are facing off after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but much of the world is refusing to take sides.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Abdi Latif Dahir and Oscar Lopez
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rubble in a residential area after an attack in the town of Borodianka, Ukraine, in April.

item.title: How hated is Macron? The answer could decide the presidency.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France spoke to factory workers this month in Le Havre.

item.title: Some Voters in a Wealthy Paris Suburb Consider Backing Le Pen
item.description: In Neuilly-sur-Seine, an upscale city west of Paris, Marine Le Pen may gain the votes of those who had supported Éric Zemmour.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting in Neuilly-sur-Seine on Sunday.

item.title: Marine Le Pen’s Message Finds a Strong Audience in the North
item.description: The far-right candidate, Marine Le Pen, has focused on kitchen-table issues, crime and immigration.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the village of Hardecourt-aux-Bois, in northern France, Marine Le Pen received 78 percent of the vote in the first round of the presidential elections.

item.title: Mother and Baby Among Those Killed in Odesa Attack
item.description: The family had moved from their apartment to a relative’s home to try to escape the Russian attacks.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Max Pshybyshevsky/Associated Press

item.title: A victory for Le Pen would be a debacle for the E.U.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen at a rally this month. Having a far-right leader with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin as France’s president would be an earthquake in the middle of Russia’s war in Ukraine.

item.title: The Perils of Legalization
item.description: We answer a common reader question about the opioid crisis and legalizing drugs.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Spencer Platt/Getty Images
item.media:description: A man walks by a billboard for a drug recovery center in Youngstown, Ohio, a city that has been struggling with a surge in opioid addiction.

item.title: ‘The Daily’ explores what’s at stake in the runoff election.
As Western Arms Pour Into Ukraine, Zelensky Promises Victory
item.description: “The day when they will be forced to leave Ukraine is approaching,” the Ukrainian president said of the Russians, in a sharp change of tone.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers pausing for early Orthodox Christian Easter services on the outskirts of Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, on Saturday, as the war’s theater shifted to the east.

item.title: Climate Activists Rally at the White House to Demand Action
item.description: In Washington, D.C., as well as Phoenix, Atlanta and scores of other cities across the country, demonstrators called on the government to enact bold climate action.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Fight for Our Future” demonstrators gathered at Lafayette Park near the White House on Saturday to protest government inaction on climate change.

item.title: Ukrainians Cling to Easter Traditions in the Shadow of a Devastating War
item.description: In Lviv, residents had laid bouquets of flowers at the feet of a statue of the Virgin Mary, next to piles of white sandbags protecting the statue from bombings.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf, Marc Santora and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A priest blessing worshippers and their food baskets a day before Easter Sunday, at Saints Peter and Paul Garrison Church in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv, on Saturday.

item.title: Missile Strikes Hit Odesa, Killing at Least Eight, Officials Say
item.description: The local authorities said at least 18 people were wounded in the strike, the first to hit Odesa since early April.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Max Pshybyshevsky/Associated Press
item.media:description: Ukrainian officials reported that several missiles were fired at the Black Sea port city of Odesa on Saturday, and that two hit a neighborhood.

item.title: 26 Missing From Japanese Tour Boat After Distress Call off Hokkaido
item.description: The sightseeing vessel was on a three-hour round trip tour to the tip of Cape Shiretoko. The Japan Coast Guard had dispatched rescue boats and aircraft to the area near the Kashuni Falls.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Makiko Inoue
item.media:credit: Kyodo News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The port on the Japanese island of Hokkaido from where a sightseeing boat left on Saturday before it was reported missing.

item.title: Inside Le Pen Territory as France Votes in a Runoff Election
item.description: Whatever happens in the runoff election on Sunday, France has changed, and the winner may face a turbulent season.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: In St. Rémy-sur-Avre, France, President Emmanuel Macron is viewed with near-universal disdain. Marine Le Pen, his far-right challenger, is seen as someone who would protect people from the onslaught of the modern world.

item.title: Melissa Clark’s Saturday Recipe
item.description: A good weekend is one in which you break with the routines of the week.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Canada’s Stanley Cup Hopes Rest on Leafs, Flames, Oilers
item.description: The N.H.L. playoffs are a beloved routine of Canadian springtime that can make fans as crazy as the season’s mercurial weather.
item.dc:creator: Shawna Richer
item.media:credit: Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Toronto Maple Leafs faced the Montreal Canadiens in the 1967 Stanley Cup Finals in Montreal.

item.title: The Drive to Vaccinate the World Against Covid Is Losing Steam
item.description: Rates are stalling in most low-income countries well short of the W.H.O.’s goal to immunize 70 percent of people in every nation. Some public health experts believe the momentum is gone forever.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker with the South Sudan Ministry of Health called for people in the Mangateen camp for internally displaced people to get their Covid vaccines in Juba last year.

item.title: Russians Seize 42 Towns in Eastern Ukraine as Fighting Intensifies
item.description: Ukrainian military officials vowed to reverse Russia’s territorial gains in what was turning into a grinding back-and-forth struggle along a front stretching more than 300 miles.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Michael Levenson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Bombs struck shopping and residential areas on Friday afternoon in the Saltivka neighborhood of Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine’s Forces, Dug In on Front Line, Fight to Repel Russia
item.description: After near-annihilation, and a marriage proposal, a Ukrainian unit has become a group of hardened veterans, dug in and determined.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: First Lt. Olena Petyak, with the 128th Separate Mountain Assault Brigade, talked with other troops near the front line in the Zaporizka region of Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: Hackers Claim to Target Russia With Cyberattacks and Leaks
item.description: While the authenticity of leaked data could not be verified, the effort appears to be part of a campaign by hackers opposed to the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Maxim Shipenkov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Red Square outside the Kremlin in Moscow. The Ukrainian government appears to have begun a parallel effort to punish Russia by publishing the names of Russian soldiers and agents of the F.S.B., a major Russian intelligence agency.

item.title: Russian General Says Kremlin Aims to Seize Southern Ukraine
item.description: A major shift in policy came from an obscure general and not the president or top commander.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Mikhail Klimentyev/Agence France-Presse, via Sputnik/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin holding an online meeting of Russia’s Security Council in Moscow, on Thursday.

item.title: Mwai Kibaki, Former President of Kenya, Dies at 90
item.description: He came to power promising to root out corruption and improve government transparency. But his tenure was blighted by widespread graft and a violent upheaval.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Tony Karumba/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Mwai Kibaki of Kenya in 2010 at the signing ceremony for Kenya's new Constitution, which promised greater freedoms and rights.

item.title: Maskless Flying
item.description: What might a more effective mask mandate look like?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting to board a plane in Atlanta.

item.title: Aliou Cissé Has Senegal Ready to Shine in World Cup
item.description: Aliou Cissé, one of the best of a new generation of African coaches, has reinvented Senegal’s national team and given the country a new sense of patriotism. His next goal: the World Cup.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Mady Camara
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senegal's national soccer team coach Aliou Cissé, 46, plays on a children's field in Diamiadio, Senegal on Thursday, March 31, 2022.

item.title: Climate Rallies Planned for White House and Across U.S.
item.description: ‘Fight for Our Future’ rallies are planned Saturday for Washington, Atlanta, Phoenix and elsewhere as supporters say time is running out for ambitious climate action.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times

item.title: As Europe Approves New Tech Laws, the U.S. Falls Further Behind
item.description: Federal privacy bills, security legislation and antitrust laws to address the power of the tech giants have all failed to advance in Congress, despite hand wringing and shows of bipartisan support.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Matt Chase

item.title: 1922: Sight of Women Smoking A Cigar Shocks Paris
item.description: Two women who shared a Havana cigar in a Parisian restaurant reportedly caused a stir.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: New Zealand Deal May Put Japan Closer to Intelligence Alliance
item.description: The two countries announced a goal of “seamless” sharing of classified information as China moves to expand its influence in the Asia-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Yuichi Yamazaki
item.media:description: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan and Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand in Tokyo on Thursday.

item.title: As Marine Le Pen Moves Closer to French Presidency, Putin Ties Persist
item.description: As elections approach Sunday, the far-right candidate is linked to the Russian president by a web of financial ties and a history of support that has hardly dimmed despite the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Mikhail Klimentyev
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen, left, the challenger for France’s presidency, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Kremlin in March 2017. She has supported his annexation of Crimea.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Putin prematurely claims victory in Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Chingis Kondarov/Reuters
item.media:description: A Russian-backed fighter in front of the destroyed administration building at the Azovstal steel factory in Mariupol, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: When Will the Tourists Be Back?
item.description: An industry weathering a long winter looks warily ahead.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Saeed Khan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Pacific Explorer cruise ship docking at Sydney Harbour on Monday.

item.title: Zelensky Says Ukraine Needs $7 Billion in Support per Month
item.description: Ukraine has suffered $550 billion in losses from the war, President Volodymyr Zelensky told the World Bank on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of a Russian rocket strike in a residential neighborhood in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: L.A. County Says Masks Are Still Required on Public Transportation
item.description: The move is a departure from California’s mask rules, which were relaxed this week after a federal judge struck down a nationwide mask mandate on public transit.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new Los Angeles County health order clarifies that people still have to wear masks on public transit, including on buses and in ride-share vehicles and airports.

item.title: Putin Claims Victory in Mariupol, Calling Off Steel Plant Assault
item.description: With casualties mounting and progress slow in his war on Ukraine, Vladimir V. Putin is eager to present it to the Russian people as a success.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian family arriving in Zaporizhzhia on Thursday after fleeing the Russian-occupied village of Tokmak, near Mariupol.

item.title: Next Phase of War Will Be Pivotal for Russia and Ukraine, U.S. Says
item.description: Reflecting a renewed sense of urgency, President Biden announced that the United States would send the Ukrainians $800 million more in military aid.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian rocket struck a residential neighborhood in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Thursday. U.S. officials still expect the war to be long and grinding.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Putin’s Defensive Speech
item.description: The Russian leader claimed victory in Mariupol, despite Ukrainian resistance.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian family who fled Mariupol arrives in Zaporizhzhia.

item.title: US Braces for Potential French Election Shockwave
item.description: An upset victory by the right-wing nationalist Marine Le Pen in the presidential election on Sunday could scramble President Biden’s foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Watching at a Paris bar as Marine Le Pen debated President Emmanuel Macron of France on Wednesday.

item.title: What to Know About the Weapons Being Sent to Ukraine
item.description: The Biden administration is sending dozens of howitzers and 120 drones in the latest $800 million package of military aid.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Stanislav Yurchenko/Reuters
item.media:description: Members of the Ukrainian Volunteer Corps operated a howitzer in the Zaporizhzhia region last month. The United States plans to send additional artillery systems as part of a new $800 million military aid package.

item.title: Mikhail Vasenkov Dies at 79; His Spy Ring Inspired ‘The Americans’
item.description: He and his wife were among 10 Soviet sleeper agents who blended into American society before being exposed and deported in 2010. The TV series sprung from the episode.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:credit: U.S. Marshals, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mikhail Vasenkov in 2010, the year he and nine others were arrested by the F.B.I. Right,
